issue.title: BUG: numpy.einsum with ellipses has different behavior when optimize=True or False.
issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

The following einsum works as expected when optimize=True but throws a ValueError when optimize=False. I believe the correct behavior is the one from optimize=True.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
x = np.array([[[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]], [[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]], [[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]]])
np.einsum('i...->i', x, optimize=True)
# array([18, 18, 18])
np.einsum('i...->i', x)
# ValueError: output has more dimensions than subscripts given in einstein sum, but no '...' ellipsis provided to broadcast the extra dimensions
```

### Error message:

```shell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<python-input-0>", line 5, in <module>
    np.einsum('i...->i', x)
    ~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "[...]/venv/lib/python3.13/site-packages/numpy/_core/einsumfunc.py", line 1423, in einsum
    return c_einsum(*operands, **kwargs)
ValueError: output has more dimensions than subscripts given in einstein sum, but no '...' ellipsis provided to broadcast the extra dimensions.
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.3.3
3.13.7 (main, Aug 15 2025, 12:34:02) [GCC 15.2.1 20250813]

### Runtime Environment:

[{'numpy_version': '2.3.3',
  'python': '3.13.7 (main, Aug 15 2025, 12:34:02) [GCC 15.2.1 20250813]',
  'uname': uname_result(system='Linux', node='desktop', release='6.17.1-arch1-1', version='#1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Mon, 06 Oct 2025 18:48:29 +0000', machine='x86_64')},
 {'simd_extensions': {'baseline': ['SSE', 'SSE2', 'SSE3'],
                      'found': ['SSSE3',
                                'SSE41',
                                'POPCNT',
                                'SSE42',
                                'AVX',
                                'F16C',
                                'FMA3',
                                'AVX2'],
                      'not_found': ['AVX512F',
                                    'AVX512CD',
                                    'AVX512_KNL',
                                    'AVX512_KNM',
                                    'AVX512_SKX',
                                    'AVX512_CLX',
                                    'AVX512_CNL',
                                    'AVX512_ICL',
                                    'AVX512_SPR']}}]
>>>

### Context for the issue:

This was one of the first things I tried after learning about einsum. It seemed like a simpler alternative to summing over every axis except the first in a tensor whose number of dimensions is not known in advance.

```python
np.einsum('i...->i', x)
```

comment.body:
> ```
> In [17]: np.einsum("i...,i...->i", x, x[0], optimize=True)
> Out[17]: array([42, 42, 42])
> ```

Yes this I agree is not well defined and should probably error, in my opinion.

I always assumed the behavior of ellipses was **"replace `...` everywhere with a matching sequence of indices, inferred from the inputs"**. That includes broadcasting, but also cases where the ellipses don't appear in the output or some inputs, but not the above case.

issue.title: ENH,DOC: Better implementation and documentation for `numpy.trapezoid`
issue.body:
I would like to contribute a much more efficient (in space in time) and slightly simpler implementation of `numpy.trapezoid`, but have some questions regarding its behavior that is not reliably documented/tested:

1. What is the purpose of this `except` case? https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/0532af47d6a815298b7841de00bdbc547104b237/numpy/lib/_function_base_impl.py#L5099-L5105 It is not documented, neither tested. So if it is useful, we should add a representative test to [`TestTrapezoid`](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/0532af47d6a815298b7841de00bdbc547104b237/numpy/lib/tests/test_function_base.py#L2294) in `numpy/lib/tests/test_function_base.py` and perhaps document what kinds of data are supported; otherwise, it would make sense to remove it.
2. The behavior for masked arrays is not documented, and [`test_masked`](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/0532af47d6a815298b7841de00bdbc547104b237/numpy/lib/tests/test_function_base.py#L2339) in fact contradicts its description (“Testing that masked arrays behave as if the function is 0 where masked”):
   ```python
   >>> import numpy as np
   >>> x = np.arange(5)
   >>> y = x * x
   >>> mask = x == 2
   >>> ym = np.ma.array(y, mask=mask)
   >>> np.trapezoid(ym, x)
   np.float64(13.0)
   >>> y0 = np.ma.filled(ym, 0)  # set masked elements to 0
   >>> np.trapezoid(y0, x)
   np.float64(18.0)
   ```
   Is this a bug or intentional? Why? There are also tests for masked `x`, but the meaning/usefulness of this is not clear.
3. The function currently accepts multidimensional `x`, but this is not clear from the documentation (I’m not sure that the phrase “this integrates along the parametric curve” correctly describes what happens) and not really tested (the only tests for ``n-d `x` `` effectively just broadcast ``1-d `x` ``). Does this need to be supported? If yes, what exactly?

comment.body: I have no memory of that anymore, sorry. There's a lot about MaskedArray handling that isn't quite right, so if you see a way to improve that code I think you can go for it.
I have updated, can you check again please :) ?

When NumPy 2.5 is branched (hopefully this weekend) we will be able to drop Python 3.11 support. That will allow us to do some long-term cleanup:

* [x] Drop `numpy.distutils` (done in gh-30340)
* [x] Clean up CI and drop 3.11 builds (xref gh-30339)

* [ ] Unpin setuptools, gets rid of four security warnings. Do we still need it?
* [ ] Update type stubs to account for [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/). (@jorenham) [#30319](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/30319)
* [ ] Clean up f2py2e to drop distutils options (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30353)
* [ ]  Expire Deprecations.

issue.title: MAINT: investigate use of warnings.warn skip_file_prefixes argument
issue.body:
>> skip_file_prefixes may sometimes be useful, and sometimes just a more cumbersome and verbose way of achieving the same thing - it depends on code structure.
> 
> From my point-of-view it's a better, less error-prone construction. Can you point to a specific example where you'd prefer to use `stacklevel`?
> 
> IMO the goal with `stacklevel` is to make sure warnings are generated with context in user code. To get that right, you need to either analyze the code or, more likely, trigger the warning and manually adjust the stacklevel so the warning context shows up in user code. If someone ever refactors the code so the stacklevel changes, they also need to adjust the warning.
> 
> Here's what I mean:
> 
> ```python
> # my_package/library.py
> import warnings
> 
> def code_that_generates_warning():
>     warnings.warn("warning!", UserWarning, stacklevel=4)
> 
> def library_function():
>     code_that_generates_warning()
> 
> def main():
>     library_function()
> ```
> 
> Here's what we see when we call the `main` function in a prompt or a file named `test_library.py`
> 
> ```
> goldbaum at Nathans-MBP in ~/Documents/test
> ○  python
> Python 3.14.0 (main, Nov  6 2025, 14:16:12) [Clang 17.0.0 (clang-1700.4.4.1)] on darwin
> Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from my_package.library import main
>>> main()
> <python-input-1>:1: UserWarning: warning!
>>> exit
> 
> goldbaum at Nathans-MBP in ~/Documents/test
> ○  python test_library.py
> /Users/goldbaum/Documents/test/test_library.py:2: UserWarning: warning!
>   main()
> ```
> 
> The users have context for what code they wrote is generating the warning. Great! 
> 
> But what happens if someone refactors or adds a new calling site for `code_that_generates_warning` with a different call stack? For the latter, suddenly there's no unique calling site. For the former, you need very careful tests of your warnings.
> 
> What does all this look like with `skip_file_prefixes`? The warnings call would look like this:
> 
> ```python
> _warn_skips = (os.path.dirname(__file__),)
> 
> def code_that_generates_warning():
>     warnings.warn("warning!", UserWarning, skip_file_prefixes=_warn_skips)
> ```
> 
> And everything works exactly as it did before, but now the warning code doesn't have to be adjusted if there's ever a refactor and `code_that_generates_warning` doesn't need logic to calculate the `stacklevel` based on the call stack above it. Not that anyone does the dynamic `stacklevel` calculation. Mostly there are a bunch of warnings in NumPy that give users context outside of their own code. 

 _Originally posted by @ngoldbaum in [#30311](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30311#issuecomment-3602664034)_

@rgommers also had some concerns so we shouldn't migrate en-mass. We should validate there aren't new corner cases, c.f. https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30311#issuecomment-3603502760

issue.title: TSK: Dropping Python 3.11 followup
issue.body:
When NumPy 2.5 is branched (hopefully this weekend) we will be able to drop Python 3.11 support. That will allow us to do some long-term cleanup:

* [x] Drop `numpy.distutils` (done in gh-30340)
* [x] Clean up CI and drop 3.11 builds (xref gh-30339)
* [ ] Remove 3.11 from nightlies and on Anaconda.
* [ ] Unpin setuptools, gets rid of four security warnings. Do we still need it?
* [ ] Update type stubs to account for [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/). (@jorenham) [#30319](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/30319)
* [ ] Clean up f2py2e to drop distutils options (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30353)
* [ ]  Expire Deprecations.

comment.body:
> I am sure there are other cases where stacklevel is equivalent or better, because a tuple of absolute path to file names constructed with __file__ is a pretty poor API: can also be broken by a refactor as soon as it contains more than just the current file, makes one wonder if it's robust with editable installs etc. when .py files are pulled in via import hooks, or say everything is compiled into a .exe with a freezing tool.

You don't need to go through `__file__`, you could set it to the package root, for example. That avoids the issue with refactoring. 

I'll have to look to see what happens with e.g. pyoxidizer.

IMO even where it's equivalent it's still less clear to use stacklevel and stacklevel still has the issue with requiring careful tests or careful refactoring.

That all said, clearly there's space to disagree here. I'll go ahead and open a separate issue for this topic so the other tasks don't get lost in this noise.

issue.title: TYP, STY: PEP 695 and other Ruff py312+ fixes
issue.body:
Follow-up of #30339 (and #30357)

After branching 2.4 we'll be able to drop support Python 3.11, opening the doors to the Python 3.12+ type parameter syntax from [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/).

Ruff actually requires that we use this new syntax now. But it waa a bit disappointing to see that Ruff's PEP695 auto-fixes (pyupgrade I believe) ignored most cases, and the ones it did "fix" it actually broke the code. So in the end I had to do almost everything by hand.

When I locally bump `requires-python`  to `>=3.12` in `pyproject.toml`, ruff, mypy, and stubtest all pass. So CI is expected to fail until that's also the case on main, hence the draft status.

There were also some other ruff errors, most of them related to now-irrelevant `if sys.version_info` code paths, that this addresses. I put those in here because I ran `ruff lint --fix`, which has to happen either way, and given the size of this PR it's basically pocket chance anyway.

Also, we no longer need `typing_extensions` (I think), so it's no longer a test dependency.

Towards #30311

comment.body:
> > There should be no need to change anything else; it's only the `type[npt.NDArray]` that this changes. So this only involves only applications of "meta-typing" such as the `check` function, where a _type expression_ itself is used as a function argument. I don't expect this to affect any `.pyi` stub files.
> 
> So a `TypeAlias` of a `_type` is OK to pass to the `check` function?

Yea exactly, an "old" `_: TypeAlias` of a type (subscripted or not) is considered as a `type` by (at least) mypy.

issue.title: ENH,DOC: Better implementation and documentation for `numpy.trapezoid`
issue.body:
I would like to contribute a much more efficient (in space in time) and slightly simpler implementation of `numpy.trapezoid`, but have some questions regarding its behavior that is not reliably documented/tested:

1. What is the purpose of this `except` case? https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/0532af47d6a815298b7841de00bdbc547104b237/numpy/lib/_function_base_impl.py#L5099-L5105 It is not documented, neither tested. So if it is useful, we should add a representative test to [`TestTrapezoid`](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/0532af47d6a815298b7841de00bdbc547104b237/numpy/lib/tests/test_function_base.py#L2294) in `numpy/lib/tests/test_function_base.py` and perhaps document what kinds of data are supported; otherwise, it would make sense to remove it.
2. The behavior for masked arrays is not documented, and [`test_masked`](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/0532af47d6a815298b7841de00bdbc547104b237/numpy/lib/tests/test_function_base.py#L2339) in fact contradicts its description (“Testing that masked arrays behave as if the function is 0 where masked”):
   ```python
   >>> import numpy as np
   >>> x = np.arange(5)
   >>> y = x * x
   >>> mask = x == 2
   >>> ym = np.ma.array(y, mask=mask)
   >>> np.trapezoid(ym, x)
   np.float64(13.0)
   >>> y0 = np.ma.filled(ym, 0)  # set masked elements to 0
   >>> np.trapezoid(y0, x)
   np.float64(18.0)
   ```
   Is this a bug or intentional? Why? There are also tests for masked `x`, but the meaning/usefulness of this is not clear.
3. The function currently accepts multidimensional `x`, but this is not clear from the documentation (I’m not sure that the phrase “this integrates along the parametric curve” correctly describes what happens) and not really tested (the only tests for ``n-d `x` `` effectively just broadcast ``1-d `x` ``). Does this need to be supported? If yes, what exactly?

comment.body:
Regarding the second question: the only related piece of history that I could find is the commit d1a661d that added ``test_masked`` with a reference to [Trac #1438](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/2036). But as I said, the actual tested result does not match the description of the test. And, in my opinion, neither really makes sense in the context of integration:
* The only _reasonable_ behavior for [`MaskedArray`](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/maskedarray.baseclass.html#numpy.ma.MaskedArray) would be to use its ``fill_value`` instead of zero.
* But the most _useful_ behavior would be to replace masked values by linear interpolation along the integration axis (the default approach in offline signal processing when no better model is known). However, this functionality is missing from ``numpy.ma``, so it will be more appropriate to implement it there.
* Taking into account this contradiction between “reasonable” and “useful”, and that “explicit is better than implicit”, maybe ``numpy.trapezoid`` should not do any guesswork and instead raise an error for masked arrays, thus requiring the users to prepare meaningful ``ndarray``s according to their intentions?

Also, it seems that ``test_masked`` was added only to test subclasses, relating to the first question above (about the ``except`` case). However, the author confesses that “for some reason I can't get masked arrays to fail without my fix”, which makes both decisions (``except`` and ``test_masked``) rather meaningless. This was ~15 years ago, but maybe @thouis and @rgommers can recall how thoughtful all this was and consider whether it is still relevant and whether it needs to remain as it is.

issue.body:
Follow-up of #30339 (and #30357)

After branching 2.4 we'll be able to drop support Python 3.11, opening the doors to the Python 3.12+ type parameter syntax from [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/).

Ruff actually requires that we use this new syntax now. But it waa a bit disappointing to see that Ruff's PEP695 auto-fixes (pyupgrade I believe) ignored most cases, and the ones it did "fix" it actually broke the code. So in the end I had to do almost everything by hand.

Also, we no longer need `typing_extensions` (I think), so it's no longer a test dependency.

Towards #30311

comment.body:
> There should be no need to change anything else; it's only the `type[npt.NDArray]` that this changes. So this only involves only applications of "meta-typing" such as the `check` function, where a _type expression_ itself is used as a function argument. I don't expect this to affect any `.pyi` stub files.

So a `TypeAlias` of a `_type` is OK to pass to the `check` function?

                        linewidth=None, suppress=None, nanstr=None, infstr=None,

comment.body:
It was partial work towards supporting general format (apparently) and I just forgot. I will work towards making the formatting more flexible in later PRs. Let's give the users the ability to format and we can gather feedback from the community to improve it. 

Now that I am sorta familiar with the formatting aspect, if there are any (new or old) issues on it I will try to take a look

Note to the community: if you can contribute with specific use cases will be nice

issue.title: TSK: Dropping Python 3.11 followup
issue.body:
When NumPy 2.5 is branched (hopefully this weekend) we will be able to drop Python 3.11 support. That will allow us to do some long-term cleanup:

* [x] Drop `numpy.distutils` (done in gh-30340)
* [x] Clean up CI and drop 3.11 builds (xref gh-30339)
* [ ] Remove 3.11 from nightlies and on Anaconda.
* [ ] Unpin setuptools, gets rid of four security warnings. Do we still need it?
* [ ] Update type stubs to account for [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/). (@jorenham) [#30319](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/30319)
* [ ] Clean up f2py2e to drop distutils options (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30353)
* [ ]  Expire Deprecations.

comment.body:
> Can you point to a specific example where you'd prefer to use `stacklevel`?

The default example in the CPython docs is a deprecation warning right above a public function. That's just cleaner with `stacklevel=2` and can't really go wrong. 

I am sure there are other cases where `stacklevel` is equivalent or better, because a tuple of absolute path to file names constructed with `__file__` is a pretty poor API: can also be broken by  a refactor as soon as it contains more than just the current file, makes one wonder if it's robust with editable installs etc. when .py files are pulled in via import hooks, or say everything is compiled into a `.exe` with a freezing tool.

And you may have cases where you want to use both at once. The docs anticipate this, they say: _"When prefixes are supplied, `stacklevel` is implicitly overridden to be `max(2, stacklevel)`."_
The `('1970-01-01T00:00:00',)` substring occurs multiple times, so that part could be extracted, e.g. using an f-string.

issue.title: BUG: Change return type of sign(timedelta64) to float64.
issue.body:
With this PR, `sign(timedelta64)` returns a `float64`.  The ensures that the sign function has the basic property `x = np.sign(x)*np.abs(x)` when `x` has dtype `timedelta64`, including the case where `x` is `NaT`.

*The PR makes the change with no warnings and no deprecation, and it has not been decided that that is OK!*  So this is a draft PR until a final decision is made about how to resolve gh-8463.

The issue was brought up on the mailing list: https://mail.python.org/archives/list/numpy-discussion@python.org/thread/7ELIJOAAZAMFIGNDAUMOCLXYBRYYKE2Z/

Closes gh-8463.
Closes gh-29496.

comment.body:
Moved to "ready to review" status.

It occurred to me that if we had an *integer with nan* type, it could be used for the sign of the floating point and timedelta64 types.  But I don't think we'll add that just to make the output of `sign()` a bit nicer.

issue.title: TYP, STY: PEP 695 and other Ruff py312+ fixes
issue.body:
Follow-up of #30339 (and #30357)

After branching 2.4 we'll be able to drop support Python 3.11, opening the doors to the Python 3.12+ type parameter syntax from [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/).

Ruff actually requires that we use this new syntax now. But it waa a bit disappointing to see that Ruff's PEP695 auto-fixes (pyupgrade I believe) ignored most cases, and the ones it did "fix" it actually broke the code. So in the end I had to do almost everything by hand.

When I locally bump `requires-python`  to `>=3.12` in `pyproject.toml`, ruff, mypy, and stubtest all pass. So CI is expected to fail until that's also the case on main, hence the draft status.

There were also some other ruff errors, most of them related to now-irrelevant `if sys.version_info` code paths, that this addresses. I put those in here because I ran `ruff lint --fix`, which has to happen either way, and given the size of this PR it's basically pocket chance anyway.

Also, we no longer need `typing_extensions` (I think), so it's no longer a test dependency.

Towards #30311

comment.body:
> Can you indicate where it no longer works? I think you're looking at where we pass `npt.NDArray` as the `klass` argument, and I think we are only doing that in one particular test file `test_plotting.py`, so if that is what you are referring to, we can change our test code to change the class we are checking to be deriving from `np.ndarray`, rather than `np.typing.NDArray` .

Yea it's indeed `test_plotting.py` I'm talking about. See https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/30319#issuecomment-3603316967 for the specific line numbers.

>  We may also have to change some of our type definitions in `pandas-stubs/_typing.pyi` . If we make that change now, will the tests still work with the current released version of `numpy` ?

There should be no need to change anything else; it's only the `type[npt.NDArray]` that this changes. So this only involves only applications of "meta-typing" such as the `check` function, where a *type expression* itself is used as a function argument. I don't expect this to affect any `.pyi` stub files.

---

Note that this change is planned for NumPy 2.5, so that'll be in roughly 7 months, so there's no hurry :)

issue.title: MAINT: Enable linting with ruff E501

labels.name: sprintable
labels.description: Issue fits the time-frame and setting of a sprint

issue.body:
Within the numpy codebase we aim to keep the maximum line length at 88 (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/27320). We will enforce the ruff [E501 rule](https://docs.astral.sh/ruff/rules/line-too-long/) for the codebase step by step:

List of files to be handled can be found in the `ruff.toml` file.


Procedure:

1. Select a couple of files to fix (for example all python files in numpy/random)
2. Update `ruff.toml` to enable ruff E501
3. Change python files to have maximum line length 88
4. If some formatting really is better with longer lines, use `# noqa: E501` to make an exception

comment.body: Agreed, -1 on pre-commit

Thanks for the feedback! Since this is a multi-line string, I can’t use # noqa because it becomes part of the text. 

Unfortunately, I don’t see a simple way to fix this without changing the string, so I’ll revert the change for now. If you have any suggestions, I’m happy to try them.

issue.body:
Follow-up of #30339 (and #30357)

After branching 2.4 we'll be able to drop support Python 3.11, opening the doors to the Python 3.12+ type parameter syntax from [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/).

Ruff actually requires that we use this new syntax now. But it waa a bit disappointing to see that Ruff's PEP695 auto-fixes (pyupgrade I believe) ignored most cases, and the ones it did "fix" it actually broke the code. So in the end I had to do almost everything by hand.

When I locally bump `requires-python`  to `>=3.12` in `pyproject.toml`, ruff, mypy, and stubtest all pass. So CI is expected to fail until that's also the case on main, hence the draft status.

There were also some other ruff errors, most of them related to now-irrelevant `if sys.version_info` code paths, that this addresses. I put those in here because I ran `ruff lint --fix`, which has to happen either way, and given the size of this PR it's basically pocket chance anyway.

Also, we no longer need `typing_extensions` (I think), so it's no longer a test dependency.

Towards #30311

comment.body:
> @Dr-Irv this change from `numpy.typing.NDArray` as `_: TypeAlias` to a `type _` (i.e. a `typing.TypeAliasType` instance), the [`check` function](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas-stubs/blob/b983c83b138f20222fee3d80d324ef1bf10e61a2/tests/__init__.py#L94) no longer seems to work (I'm guessing also at runtime).

Can you indicate where it no longer works?  I think you're looking at where we pass `npt.NDArray` as the `klass` argument, and I think we are only doing that in one particular test file `test_plotting.py`, so if that is what you are referring to, we can change our test code to change the class we are checking to be deriving from `np.ndarray`, rather than `np.typing.NDArray` .  We may also have to change some of our type definitions in `pandas-stubs/_typing.pyi` .   If we make that change now, will the tests still work with the current released version of `numpy` ?

issue.title: TYP, STY: PEP 695 and other Ruff py312+ fixes
issue.body:
Follow-up of #30339 (and #30357)

After branching 2.4 we'll be able to drop support Python 3.11, opening the doors to the Python 3.12+ type parameter syntax from [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/).

Ruff actually requires that we use this new syntax now. But it waa a bit disappointing to see that Ruff's PEP695 auto-fixes (pyupgrade I believe) ignored most cases, and the ones it did "fix" it actually broke the code. So in the end I had to do almost everything by hand.

When I locally bump `requires-python`  to `>=3.12` in `pyproject.toml`, ruff, mypy, and stubtest all pass. So CI is expected to fail until that's also the case on main, hence the draft status.

There were also some other ruff errors, most of them related to now-irrelevant `if sys.version_info` code paths, that this addresses. I put those in here because I ran `ruff lint --fix`, which has to happen either way, and given the size of this PR it's basically pocket chance anyway.

Also, we no longer need `typing_extensions` (I think), so it's no longer a test dependency.

Towards #30311

issue.title: MAINT: Enable linting with ruff E501

labels.name: sprintable
labels.description: Issue fits the time-frame and setting of a sprint

issue.body:
Within the numpy codebase we aim to keep the maximum line length at 88 (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/27320). We will enforce the ruff [E501 rule](https://docs.astral.sh/ruff/rules/line-too-long/) for the codebase step by step:

List of files to be handled can be found in the `ruff.toml` file.


Procedure:

1. Select a couple of files to fix (for example all python files in numpy/random)
2. Update `ruff.toml` to enable ruff E501
3. Change python files to have maximum line length 88
4. If some formatting really is better with longer lines, use `# noqa: E501` to make an exception

issue.title: TYP, STY: PEP 695 and other Ruff py312+ fixes
issue.body:
Follow-up of #30339 (and #30357)

After branching 2.4 we'll be able to drop support Python 3.11, opening the doors to the Python 3.12+ type parameter syntax from [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/).

Ruff actually requires that we use this new syntax now. But it waa a bit disappointing to see that Ruff's PEP695 auto-fixes (pyupgrade I believe) ignored most cases, and the ones it did "fix" it actually broke the code. So in the end I had to do almost everything by hand.

When I locally bump `requires-python`  to `>=3.12` in `pyproject.toml`, ruff, mypy, and stubtest all pass. So CI is expected to fail until that's also the case on main, hence the draft status.

There were also some other ruff errors, most of them related to now-irrelevant `if sys.version_info` code paths, that this addresses. I put those in here because I ran `ruff lint --fix`, which has to happen either way, and given the size of this PR it's basically pocket chance anyway.

Also, we no longer need `typing_extensions` (I think), so it's no longer a test dependency.

Towards #30311

issue.title: TYP, STY: PEP 695 and other Ruff py312+ fixes
issue.body:
Follow-up of #30339 (and #30357)

After branching 2.4 we'll be able to drop support Python 3.11, opening the doors to the Python 3.12+ type parameter syntax from [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/).

Ruff actually requires that we use this new syntax now. But it waa a bit disappointing to see that Ruff's PEP695 auto-fixes (pyupgrade I believe) ignored most cases, and the ones it did "fix" it actually broke the code. So in the end I had to do almost everything by hand.

When I locally bump `requires-python`  to `>=3.12` in `pyproject.toml`, ruff, mypy, and stubtest all pass. So CI is expected to fail until that's also the case on main, hence the draft status.

There were also some other ruff errors, most of them related to now-irrelevant `if sys.version_info` code paths, that this addresses. I put those in here because I ran `ruff lint --fix`, which has to happen either way, and given the size of this PR it's basically pocket chance anyway.

Also, we no longer need `typing_extensions` (I think), so it's no longer a test dependency.

Towards #30311

issue.title: BUG: default BLAS to LP64 and add Alpine preload smoke test
issue.body:
Hello,

We recently hit a segfault on Alpine when importing NumPy in a process that had already loaded the system OpenBLAS. After some investigation, it seems Alpine’s system OpenBLAS is LP64 (32-bit BLAS ints) while the musllinux wheels default to ILP64 (64-bit BLAS ints), and mixing the two in one process can crash (seen via a reticulate workflow, https://github.com/rstudio/reticulate/issues/1858#issuecomment-3549517694). From what I can tell, most distro OpenBLAS packages (including Alpine) and MKL defaults are LP64, while manylinux wheels use ILP64 for large-array support, so this change tries to align musl builds with the system default, but please let me know if I’m missing a better precedent.

What changed

- Add a Meson option allow-ilp64-on-musl (default false).
- Detect musl at configure time and force LP64 BLAS/LAPACK unless the new flag is set; ILP64 stays opt-in. glibc/macOS/Windows unchanged.
- Add a manual workflow (alpine_musl.yml + Dockerfile) to smoke-test on Alpine with and without `LD_PRELOAD=/usr/lib/libopenblas.so.3`.

Testing

- macOS host: built from source, ran `numpy.test(verbose=0, extra_argv=['-q'])` from `/tmp` (pass).
- Alpine 3.20 (docker, aarch64 and x86_64) with system OpenBLAS: built from source and ran numpy.test(verbose=0, extra_argv=['-q', '-k', 'not test_to_ctypes']) both normally and with LD_PRELOAD=/usr/lib/libopenblas.so.3; all passed.

Happy to adjust anything. Thanks!

comment.body: yeah, I see. When the DLL is opened `void gotoblas_init(void)` is called to set stuff up. It would have to be called manually somehow.

issue.title: BUG: Confusing error message when `numpy` importing `numpy.__config__` raises `ImportError` for legit reasons

labels.name: 57 - Close?
labels.description: Issues which may be closable unless discussion continued

issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

When the `numpy` module imports `numpy.__config__`, and this fails, it raises `ImportError` with the following message:

> Error importing numpy: you should not try to import numpy from its source directory; please exit the numpy source tree, and relaunch your python interpreter from there.

This makes sense when someone imports `numpy` from source: `__config__.py` does not exist, and one should install NumPy properly. But! The statement “`import numpy.__config__` raises `ImportError`, therefore `__config__.py` does not exist” does not hold. `__config__.py` imports many modules transitively, and if any of those imports fail, this also raises `ImportError`. (This was the case for me due to issues with the dynamic linker, but that problem is outside the scope of this issue.)

Ideally, the code should check it was really `numpy.__config__` that could not be imported. Otherwise, just reraise the original exception instead of wrapping it:

```diff
     try:
         from numpy.__config__ import show_config
     except ImportError as e:
+        if e.name != "numpy.__config__":
+            raise
         msg = """Error importing numpy: you should not try to import numpy from
         its source directory; please exit the numpy source tree, and relaunch
         your python interpreter from there."""
         raise ImportError(msg) from e
```

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy
```

### Error message:

Note: most of this traceback is irrelevant to this issue. This issue is only about the last bit (the outermost exception, not its `__cause__`). Note also that in many contexts, exceptions’ `__cause__`s are not displayed (in my case it was PyO3’s `Debug for PyErr`). I was very confused until I tried to import `numpy` in a REPL and got to see the actual error.

```shell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/_core/__init__.py", line 23, in <module>
    from . import multiarray
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/_core/multiarray.py", line 10, in <module>
    from . import overrides
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/_core/overrides.py", line 7, in <module>
    from numpy._core._multiarray_umath import (
ImportError: libstdc++.so.6: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py", line 114, in <module>
    from numpy.__config__ import show_config
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/__config__.py", line 4, in <module>
    from numpy._core._multiarray_umath import (
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/_core/__init__.py", line 49, in <module>
    raise ImportError(msg)
ImportError: 

IMPORTANT: PLEASE READ THIS FOR ADVICE ON HOW TO SOLVE THIS ISSUE!

Importing the numpy C-extensions failed. This error can happen for
many reasons, often due to issues with your setup or how NumPy was
installed.

We have compiled some common reasons and troubleshooting tips at:

    https://numpy.org/devdocs/user/troubleshooting-importerror.html

Please note and check the following:

  * The Python version is: Python3.12 from "/home/r/azalea/.venv/bin/python3"
  * The NumPy version is: "2.2.5"

and make sure that they are the versions you expect.
Please carefully study the documentation linked above for further help.

Original error was: libstdc++.so.6: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory


The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py", line 119, in <module>
    raise ImportError(msg) from e
ImportError: Error importing numpy: you should not try to import numpy from
        its source directory; please exit the numpy source tree, and relaunch
        your python interpreter from there.
```

issue.title: TSK: Dropping Python 3.11 followup
issue.body:
When NumPy 2.5 is branched (hopefully this weekend) we will be able to drop Python 3.11 support. That will allow us to do some long-term cleanup:

* [x] Drop `numpy.distutils` (done in gh-30340)
* [x] Clean up CI and drop 3.11 builds (xref gh-30339)
* [ ] Remove 3.11 from nightlies and on Anaconda.
* [ ] Unpin setuptools, gets rid of four security warnings. Do we still need it?
* [ ] Update type stubs to account for [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/). (@jorenham) [#30319](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/30319)
* [ ] Clean up f2py2e to drop distutils options (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30353)
* [ ]  Expire Deprecations.

comment.body:
> skip_file_prefixes may sometimes be useful, and sometimes just a more cumbersome and verbose way of achieving the same thing - it depends on code structure.

From my point-of-view it's a better, less error-prone construction. Can you point to a specific example where you'd prefer to use `stacklevel`?

IMO the goal with `stacklevel` is to make sure warnings are generated with context in user code. To get that right, you need to either analyze the code or, more likely, trigger the warning and manually adjust the stacklevel so the warning context shows up in user code. If someone ever refactors the code so the stacklevel changes, they also need to adjust the warning.

Here's what I mean:

```python
# my_package/library.py
import warnings

def code_that_generates_warning():
    warnings.warn("warning!", UserWarning, stacklevel=4)

def library_function():
    code_that_generates_warning()

def main():
    library_function()
```

Here's what we see when we call the `main` function in a prompt or a file named `test_library.py`

```
goldbaum at Nathans-MBP in ~/Documents/test
○  python
Python 3.14.0 (main, Nov  6 2025, 14:16:12) [Clang 17.0.0 (clang-1700.4.4.1)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from my_package.library import main
>>> main()
<python-input-1>:1: UserWarning: warning!
>>> exit

goldbaum at Nathans-MBP in ~/Documents/test
○  python test_library.py
/Users/goldbaum/Documents/test/test_library.py:2: UserWarning: warning!
  main()
```

The users have context for what code they wrote is generating the warning. Great! 

But what happens if someone refactors or adds a new calling site for `code_that_generates_warning` with a different call stack? For the latter, suddenly there's no unique calling site. For the former, you need very careful tests of your warnings.

What does all this look like with `skip_file_prefixes`? The warnings call would look like this:

```python
_warn_skips = (os.path.dirname(__file__),)

def code_that_generates_warning():
    warnings.warn("warning!", UserWarning, skip_file_prefixes=_warn_skips)
```

And everything works exactly as it did before, but now the warning code doesn't have to be adjusted if there's ever a refactor and `code_that_generates_warning` doesn't need logic to calculate the `stacklevel` based on the call stack above it. Not that anyone does the dynamic `stacklevel` calculation. Mostly there are a bunch of warnings in NumPy that give users context outside of their own code.

Specializing loops for aligned SIMD load and store operations is generally unnecessary, as modern CPUs handle unaligned memory accesses effectively.

issue.title: BUG: Confusing error message when `numpy` importing `numpy.__config__` raises `ImportError` for legit reasons

labels.name: 57 - Close?
labels.description: Issues which may be closable unless discussion continued

issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

When the `numpy` module imports `numpy.__config__`, and this fails, it raises `ImportError` with the following message:

> Error importing numpy: you should not try to import numpy from its source directory; please exit the numpy source tree, and relaunch your python interpreter from there.

This makes sense when someone imports `numpy` from source: `__config__.py` does not exist, and one should install NumPy properly. But! The statement “`import numpy.__config__` raises `ImportError`, therefore `__config__.py` does not exist” does not hold. `__config__.py` imports many modules transitively, and if any of those imports fail, this also raises `ImportError`. (This was the case for me due to issues with the dynamic linker, but that problem is outside the scope of this issue.)

Ideally, the code should check it was really `numpy.__config__` that could not be imported. Otherwise, just reraise the original exception instead of wrapping it:

```diff
     try:
         from numpy.__config__ import show_config
     except ImportError as e:
+        if e.name != "numpy.__config__":
+            raise
         msg = """Error importing numpy: you should not try to import numpy from
         its source directory; please exit the numpy source tree, and relaunch
         your python interpreter from there."""
         raise ImportError(msg) from e
```

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy
```

### Error message:

Note: most of this traceback is irrelevant to this issue. This issue is only about the last bit (the outermost exception, not its `__cause__`). Note also that in many contexts, exceptions’ `__cause__`s are not displayed (in my case it was PyO3’s `Debug for PyErr`). I was very confused until I tried to import `numpy` in a REPL and got to see the actual error.

```shell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/_core/__init__.py", line 23, in <module>
    from . import multiarray
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/_core/multiarray.py", line 10, in <module>
    from . import overrides
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/_core/overrides.py", line 7, in <module>
    from numpy._core._multiarray_umath import (
ImportError: libstdc++.so.6: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py", line 114, in <module>
    from numpy.__config__ import show_config
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/__config__.py", line 4, in <module>
    from numpy._core._multiarray_umath import (
  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/_core/__init__.py", line 49, in <module>
    raise ImportError(msg)
ImportError: 

IMPORTANT: PLEASE READ THIS FOR ADVICE ON HOW TO SOLVE THIS ISSUE!

Importing the numpy C-extensions failed. This error can happen for
many reasons, often due to issues with your setup or how NumPy was
installed.

We have compiled some common reasons and troubleshooting tips at:

    https://numpy.org/devdocs/user/troubleshooting-importerror.html

Please note and check the following:

  * The Python version is: Python3.12 from "/home/r/azalea/.venv/bin/python3"
  * The NumPy version is: "2.2.5"

and make sure that they are the versions you expect.
Please carefully study the documentation linked above for further help.

  File "/home/r/azalea/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py", line 119, in <module>
    raise ImportError(msg) from e
ImportError: Error importing numpy: you should not try to import numpy from
        its source directory; please exit the numpy source tree, and relaunch
        your python interpreter from there.
```

comment.body:
> Basically, this error happens when something is deeply broken with importing NumPy's C extensions. Historically the way to trigger it was trying to import NumPy from its own source directory but it seems other changes have made it more likely to trigger in other situations.

One of the other causes (which I just hit) is when one of the SO files was stripped and you end up with `ELF load command address/offset not page-aligned`. It would be helpful to see that that was the problem without adding `try...except...` blocks and different ways of printing the error and the stack trace!

On the one hand, yes, the SO file probably shouldn't have been stripped. On the other hand, it has been working fine with the default stripping (packaging for AWS Lambda using Serverless) for the last three years!

issue.title: BUG: min_scalar_type returns wrong datatype for high values of float 32
issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

The min_scalar_type function returns the incorrect data type for values close to the maximum float32. Using the finfo function, I extracted the maximum values of a float32.

```
float_32_max = np.finfo("float32").max
print(float_32_max)
```

> 3.4028235e38

However when I use it to determine the minmum scalar type float64 is returned


Also reducing the number a bit does not help e.g. 


```
detected_data_type = np.min_scalar_type(3.402e38)
print(detected_data_type)
```

> float64

```
float_64_max = np.finfo("float64").max
print(float_64_max)
detected_data_type = np.min_scalar_type(1.7976931348623157e308)
print(detected_data_type) 
```
> 1.7976931348623157e+308
> float64

This works properly for float 64

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

float_32_max = np.finfo("float32").max
print(float_32_max)
detected_data_type = np.min_scalar_type(3.4028235e38)
print(detected_data_type)


float_64_max = np.finfo("float64").max
print(float_64_max)
detected_data_type = np.min_scalar_type(1.7976931348623157e308)
print(detected_data_type)


detected_data_type = np.min_scalar_type(3.402e38)
print(detected_data_type)
```

comment.body:
@jorenham, yeah I don't really like to bring it up on random issues that are really unrelated. There are longer discussions elsewhere on open issues.

Plus IMO this discussion about _removing_ scalars is counter-produtive to begin with. The realistic first step is to stop creating scalars for no good reason. That is far clearer achievable and already a big enough thing that it is tricky.  Helping to push that may put energy in a useful direction.
IMO bringing up removing scalars does the opposite because it just builds up hope to do something that we have no idea if we can actually pull it off.  At least I don't believe you'll find someone to start working on it who then will keep going and form a years long plan when we realize that the downstream impact is far more complicated than you thought it is (I am confident about this, happy to be convinced otherwise, but frankly, I don't remember anyone ever really argued against this, the argument against scalars is all from a principle point of view, which is fair, but not helpful).
You can't duck-type immutability/hashibility easily, you could _implement_ scalars differently, but that isn't "removing" them.

comment.body:
I dunno either, but the main point of this function was probably never to give you a true minimum type but rather to say that `np.array([4.], dtype=float32) + 4e38` will return a float32 (and then happily overflow while doing the computation).

That odd behavior was removed in NumPy 2, meaning that this function is really more of an artifact than anything else. Doesn't mean you can't use it for this very specific use-case, but it's an odd one for sure.

comment.body:
Jeeesh. This is broken in three ways:
* Scalars export `__array_interface__` by creating an array and exporting the interface with an additional (I believe undocumented) `__ref` field.
* I don't see why they use a helper array at all for the `__array_interface__`, except maybe for strings, but even there you could do without.
* `ctypeslib` uses the `__array_interface__` not knowing about that weird convention.

issue.title: BUG: numpy.einsum with ellipses has different behavior when optimize=True or False.
issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

The following einsum works as expected when optimize=True but throws a ValueError when optimize=False. I believe the correct behavior is the one from optimize=True.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
x = np.array([[[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]], [[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]], [[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]]])
np.einsum('i...->i', x, optimize=True)
# array([18, 18, 18])
np.einsum('i...->i', x)
# ValueError: output has more dimensions than subscripts given in einstein sum, but no '...' ellipsis provided to broadcast the extra dimensions
```

### Error message:

```shell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<python-input-0>", line 5, in <module>
    np.einsum('i...->i', x)
    ~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "[...]/venv/lib/python3.13/site-packages/numpy/_core/einsumfunc.py", line 1423, in einsum
    return c_einsum(*operands, **kwargs)
ValueError: output has more dimensions than subscripts given in einstein sum, but no '...' ellipsis provided to broadcast the extra dimensions.
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.3.3
3.13.7 (main, Aug 15 2025, 12:34:02) [GCC 15.2.1 20250813]

### Runtime Environment:

[{'numpy_version': '2.3.3',
  'python': '3.13.7 (main, Aug 15 2025, 12:34:02) [GCC 15.2.1 20250813]',
  'uname': uname_result(system='Linux', node='desktop', release='6.17.1-arch1-1', version='#1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Mon, 06 Oct 2025 18:48:29 +0000', machine='x86_64')},
 {'simd_extensions': {'baseline': ['SSE', 'SSE2', 'SSE3'],
                      'found': ['SSSE3',
                                'SSE41',
                                'POPCNT',
                                'SSE42',
                                'AVX',
                                'F16C',
                                'FMA3',
                                'AVX2'],
                      'not_found': ['AVX512F',
                                    'AVX512CD',
                                    'AVX512_KNL',
                                    'AVX512_KNM',
                                    'AVX512_SKX',
                                    'AVX512_CLX',
                                    'AVX512_CNL',
                                    'AVX512_ICL',
                                    'AVX512_SPR']}}]
>>>

### Context for the issue:

This was one of the first things I tried after learning about einsum. It seemed like a simpler alternative to summing over every axis except the first in a tensor whose number of dimensions is not known in advance.

```python
np.einsum('i...->i', x)
```

comment.body:
This needs new logic I would imagine. My understanding is that `...` is implemented as indicated _broadcasting_ dimensions and while this overloads it as an arbitrary number of reduce dimensions with the name `...`.

It gets a bit more unclear to me that this works:
```
In [17]: np.einsum("i...,i...->i", x, x[0], optimize=True)
Out[17]: array([42, 42, 42])
```
where I guess the `...` of the second operand are actually broadcast to fit the first (not sure, it might be weirder). It isn't clear to me that the intention is clear there.

I do agree that this intention seems like a sensible generalization, but it is a bit unclear that broadcasting is actually sensible for reduced dimensions with multiple operands.

issue.title: BUG: f2py does not correctly handle double complex type when using iso_fortran_env kinds
issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

When declaring a double complex variable in a Fortran program using either `iso_c_binding` or  `iso_fortran_env` to handle its kind, i.e. `complex(kind=dp)`, `f2py` maps it to a single precision complex C 
variable `typedef struct {float r,i;} complex_float;` instead of the expected double precision. This yields a segfault of the program. This is working fine when the variable is declared in the old-fashioned format `complex(kind=8)` .
Here is a quick reproducer:

```fortran
module test

   use iso_fortran_env, only: dp=>real64

   implicit none

contains

   subroutine test_function(arr, nt)

      integer :: nt
      ! complex(kind=8), intent(inout) :: arr(nt) ! This is OK but not standard
      complex(kind=dp), intent(inout) :: arr(nt) ! This is segfaulting
                                                 ! C file declares it as a 
                                                 ! typedef struct {float r,i;} complex_float;

      arr(:) = (1.0_dp,-1.0_dp)

   end subroutine test_function

end module test
```
and the associated python function

```python
from test import *
import numpy as np

x = np.zeros((10), np.complex128)
test.test_function(x)
print(x)
```

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
from test import *
import numpy as np

x = np.zeros((10), np.complex128)
test.test_function(x)
print(x)
```

### Error message:

```shell

```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.2.2
3.13.5 (main, Aug 19 2025, 14:39:27) [GCC]

### Runtime Environment:

_No response_

### Context for the issue:

_No response_

issue.title: BUG: ndarray.__dlpack__ should raise `BufferError` instead of `ValueError` on unsupported `dl_device` values

labels.name: 40 - array API standard
labels.description: PRs and issues related to support for the array API standard

issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

According to the DLPack Python specs (part of the array API specs):

https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/API_specification/generated/array_api.array.__dlpack__.html#:~:text=dl_device,-(Optional

> When specified, the format must be a 2-tuple, following that of the return value of [`array.__dlpack_device__()`](https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/API_specification/generated/array_api.array.__dlpack_device__.html#array_api.array.__dlpack_device__). If the device type cannot be handled by the producer, this function must raise BufferError.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
np.ones(3).__dlpack__(max_version=(1, 0), dl_device=(8, 0))  # PyTorch MPS device.
```

### Error message:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  Cell In[3], line 2
    np.ones(3).__dlpack__(max_version=(1, 0), dl_device=(8, 0))
ValueError: unsupported device requested
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.3.3
3.13.7 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Sep  3 2025, 14:24:46) [Clang 19.1.7 ]

### Runtime Environment:

```python
[{'numpy_version': '2.3.3',
  'python': '3.13.7 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Sep  3 2025, 14:24:46) '
            '[Clang 19.1.7 ]',
  'uname': uname_result(system='Darwin', node='fuligule.local', release='24.6.0', version='Darwin Kernel Version 24.6.0: Mon Jul 14 11:30:40 PDT 2025; root:xnu-11417.140.69~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T8132', machine='arm64')},
 {'simd_extensions': {'baseline': ['NEON', 'NEON_FP16', 'NEON_VFPV4', 'ASIMD'],
                      'found': ['ASIMDHP'],
                      'not_found': ['ASIMDFHM']}},
 {'architecture': 'VORTEX',
  'filepath': '/Users/ogrisel/miniforge3/envs/dev/lib/libopenblas.0.dylib',
  'internal_api': 'openblas',
  'num_threads': 10,
  'prefix': 'libopenblas',
  'threading_layer': 'openmp',
  'user_api': 'blas',
  'version': '0.3.30'},
 {'filepath': '/Users/ogrisel/miniforge3/envs/dev/lib/libomp.dylib',
  'internal_api': 'openmp',
  'num_threads': 10,
  'prefix': 'libomp',
  'user_api': 'openmp',
  'version': None}]
```

### Context for the issue:

Fixing this would allow scikit-learn to properly work with PyTorch 2.9 that now includes support for DLPack 1.0 when enabling the array API support of scikit-learn.

Under the hood, scikit-learn would like the following code should either directly to do the device transfer by itself or raise `BufferError` as specified in the standard so that scikit-learn needs to fall back to library specific device to CPU transfer.

```python
>>> import torch
>>> import numpy as np
>>> torch.from_dlpack(np.ones(3, dtype=np.float32), device="mps")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  Cell In[56], line 1
    torch.from_dlpack(np.ones(3, dtype=np.float32), device="mps")
  File ~/miniforge3/envs/tmp/lib/python3.13/site-packages/torch/utils/dlpack.py:159 in from_dlpack
    dlpack = ext_tensor.__dlpack__(**kwargs)
ValueError: unsupported device requested
```

https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/API_specification/generated/array_api.array.__dlpack__.html#:~:text=dl_device,-(Optional

> When specified, the format must be a 2-tuple, following that of the return value of [`array.__dlpack_device__()`](https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/API_specification/generated/array_api.array.__dlpack_device__.html#array_api.array.__dlpack_device__). If the device type cannot be handled by the producer, this function must raise BufferError.

comment.body:
Ah, I suppose this one actually would usually come from a bad user request, so it sits maybe at a slightly awkward point where it isn't quite obvious that `BufferError` is best (it's not like there is a real chance that a different path for exporting might work if you want that device).

But I also don't see a downside in just using `BufferError` here, since I guess here it is somewhat used in the way of "can we export?".

issue.title: TSK: Dropping Python 3.11 followup
issue.body:
When NumPy 2.5 is branched (hopefully this weekend) we will be able to drop Python 3.11 support. That will allow us to do some long-term cleanup:

* [x] Drop `numpy.distutils` (done in gh-30340)
* [x] Clean up CI and drop 3.11 builds (xref gh-30339)
* [ ] Remove 3.11 from nightlies and on Anaconda.
* [ ] Unpin setuptools, gets rid of four security warnings. Do we still need it?
* [ ] Update type stubs to account for [PEP 695](https://peps.python.org/pep-0695/). (@jorenham) [#30319](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/30319)
* [ ] Clean up f2py2e to drop distutils options (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30353)
* [ ]  Expire Deprecations.

comment.body:
>  Unpin setuptools, gets rid of four security warnings. Do we still need it?

We will no longer need that pin. We do still need `setuptools` as a test dependency for some compile tests.

> Replace `warnings.warn` `stacklevel` keyword argument with [`skip_file_prefixes`]

This looks like a separate thing from the topic in this issue, and not a good idea to do wholesale. `skip_file_prefixes` may sometimes be useful, and sometimes just a more cumbersome and verbose way of achieving the same thing - it depends on code structure.

review.body: A bunch of little things to finalize, but overall looks great (and a very satisfying PR:)). Thanks @mattip!

issue.title: BUG: f2py does not correctly handle double complex type when using iso_fortran_env kinds
issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

When declaring a double complex variable in a Fortran program using either `iso_c_binding` or  `iso_fortran_env` to handle its kind, i.e. `complex(kind=dp)`, `f2py` maps it to a single precision complex C 
variable `typedef struct {float r,i;} complex_float;` instead of the expected double precision. This yields a segfault of the program. This is working fine when the variable is declared in the old-fashioned format `complex(kind=8)` .
Here is a quick reproducer:

```fortran
module test

   use iso_fortran_env, only: dp=>real64

   implicit none

contains

   subroutine test_function(arr, nt)

      integer :: nt
      ! complex(kind=8), intent(inout) :: arr(nt) ! This is OK but not standard
      complex(kind=dp), intent(inout) :: arr(nt) ! This is segfaulting
                                                 ! C file declares it as a 
                                                 ! typedef struct {float r,i;} complex_float;

      arr(:) = (1.0_dp,-1.0_dp)

   end subroutine test_function

end module test
```
and the associated python function

```python
from test import *
import numpy as np

x = np.zeros((10), np.complex128)
test.test_function(x)
print(x)
```

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
from test import *
import numpy as np

x = np.zeros((10), np.complex128)
test.test_function(x)
print(x)
```

### Error message:

```shell

```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.2.2
3.13.5 (main, Aug 19 2025, 14:39:27) [GCC]

### Runtime Environment:

_No response_

### Context for the issue:

_No response_

issue.title: BUG: ndarray.__dlpack__ should raise `BufferError` instead of `ValueError` on unsupported `dl_device` values

labels.name: 40 - array API standard
labels.description: PRs and issues related to support for the array API standard

issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

According to the DLPack Python specs (part of the array API specs):

https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/API_specification/generated/array_api.array.__dlpack__.html#:~:text=dl_device,-(Optional

> When specified, the format must be a 2-tuple, following that of the return value of [`array.__dlpack_device__()`](https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/API_specification/generated/array_api.array.__dlpack_device__.html#array_api.array.__dlpack_device__). If the device type cannot be handled by the producer, this function must raise BufferError.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
np.ones(3).__dlpack__(max_version=(1, 0), dl_device=(8, 0))  # PyTorch MPS device.
```

### Error message:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  Cell In[3], line 2
    np.ones(3).__dlpack__(max_version=(1, 0), dl_device=(8, 0))
ValueError: unsupported device requested
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.3.3
3.13.7 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Sep  3 2025, 14:24:46) [Clang 19.1.7 ]

### Runtime Environment:

```python
[{'numpy_version': '2.3.3',
  'python': '3.13.7 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Sep  3 2025, 14:24:46) '
            '[Clang 19.1.7 ]',
  'uname': uname_result(system='Darwin', node='fuligule.local', release='24.6.0', version='Darwin Kernel Version 24.6.0: Mon Jul 14 11:30:40 PDT 2025; root:xnu-11417.140.69~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T8132', machine='arm64')},
 {'simd_extensions': {'baseline': ['NEON', 'NEON_FP16', 'NEON_VFPV4', 'ASIMD'],
                      'found': ['ASIMDHP'],
                      'not_found': ['ASIMDFHM']}},
 {'architecture': 'VORTEX',
  'filepath': '/Users/ogrisel/miniforge3/envs/dev/lib/libopenblas.0.dylib',
  'internal_api': 'openblas',
  'num_threads': 10,
  'prefix': 'libopenblas',
  'threading_layer': 'openmp',
  'user_api': 'blas',
  'version': '0.3.30'},
 {'filepath': '/Users/ogrisel/miniforge3/envs/dev/lib/libomp.dylib',
  'internal_api': 'openmp',
  'num_threads': 10,
  'prefix': 'libomp',
  'user_api': 'openmp',
  'version': None}]
```

### Context for the issue:

Fixing this would allow scikit-learn to properly work with PyTorch 2.9 that now includes support for DLPack 1.0 when enabling the array API support of scikit-learn.

Under the hood, scikit-learn would like the following code should either directly to do the device transfer by itself or raise `BufferError` as specified in the standard so that scikit-learn needs to fall back to library specific device to CPU transfer.

```python
>>> import torch
>>> import numpy as np
>>> torch.from_dlpack(np.ones(3, dtype=np.float32), device="mps")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  Cell In[56], line 1
    torch.from_dlpack(np.ones(3, dtype=np.float32), device="mps")
  File ~/miniforge3/envs/tmp/lib/python3.13/site-packages/torch/utils/dlpack.py:159 in from_dlpack
    dlpack = ext_tensor.__dlpack__(**kwargs)
ValueError: unsupported device requested
```

comment.body:
This was just missed somewhere (I am surprised), we tried to make sure this is nice in NumPy.

The point of `BufferError` is to clearly indicate: I can't export the the data with this protocol. As opposed to any other error that would indicate "bad input" in some other form.

Frankly, I am surprised about the *must* part the specs often writes should when it means must and I thought `pytorch` gets it wrong everywhere.

issue.title: BUG: C code generated by f2py is not C23 compliant
issue.body:
Fix #30167 

This PR  updates the condition to `if r and r.strip():`, the code now properly ignores empty or whitespace only blocks. This ensures that when no arguments are provided, F2PY correctly falls back to generating `void` as the argument list, producing a valid and C23-compliant function signature.

Please let me know if my approach or fix needs any improvements . I’m open to feedback and happy to make changes based on suggestions.
Thankyou !

comment.body:
I'm not sure if your understanding is incorrect, hard to tell without actually doing the reproducing/testing that you didn't manage here - which is most of the work. Since I don't have time to do that, I'll move this to draft. 

Note that you don't actually need GCC 15 to test this yourself, if that was your problem. Any compiler is fine, since `f2py` gives the same output. You could try to build `scikits.odes` with and without this patch, and just diff the files generated by `f2py`.

issue.title: MAINT: Enable linting with ruff E501

labels.name: sprintable
labels.description: Issue fits the time-frame and setting of a sprint

issue.body:
Within the numpy codebase we aim to keep the maximum line length at 88 (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/27320). We will enforce the ruff [E501 rule](https://docs.astral.sh/ruff/rules/line-too-long/) for the codebase step by step:

List of files to be handled can be found in the `ruff.toml` file.


Procedure:

1. Select a couple of files to fix (for example all python files in numpy/random)
2. Update `ruff.toml` to enable ruff E501
3. Change python files to have maximum line length 88
4. If some formatting really is better with longer lines, use `# noqa: E501` to make an exception

comment.body: The list has not been updated, but the `ruff.toml` file should reflect what is still to be done.

issue.title: MAINT: remove ``numpy.distutils``
issue.body:
Remove numpy.distutils after the 2.5 branch 

- remove the module
- move `numpy.distutils/conv_template.py` to `numpy/_build_utils/conv_template.py`
- move `numpy/distutils/checks` to `numpy/_core/src/_simd/checks`
- remove references from documentation, tests, typing stubs.
- inline a helper function that used importlib 

The tricky part was removing the `f2py/_backend` and adjusting the `f2pye` script. I tried to check `spin docs`, `spin test`, `spin check-docs`, `spin check-tutorials`.

issue.title: BUG: ndarray.__dlpack__ should raise `BufferError` instead of `ValueError` on unsupported `dl_device` values

labels.name: 40 - array API standard
labels.description: PRs and issues related to support for the array API standard

issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

According to the DLPack Python specs (part of the array API specs):

https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/API_specification/generated/array_api.array.__dlpack__.html#:~:text=dl_device,-(Optional

> When specified, the format must be a 2-tuple, following that of the return value of [`array.__dlpack_device__()`](https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/API_specification/generated/array_api.array.__dlpack_device__.html#array_api.array.__dlpack_device__). If the device type cannot be handled by the producer, this function must raise BufferError.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
np.ones(3).__dlpack__(max_version=(1, 0), dl_device=(8, 0))  # PyTorch MPS device.
```

### Error message:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  Cell In[3], line 2
    np.ones(3).__dlpack__(max_version=(1, 0), dl_device=(8, 0))
ValueError: unsupported device requested
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.3.3
3.13.7 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Sep  3 2025, 14:24:46) [Clang 19.1.7 ]

### Runtime Environment:

```python
[{'numpy_version': '2.3.3',
  'python': '3.13.7 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Sep  3 2025, 14:24:46) '
            '[Clang 19.1.7 ]',
  'uname': uname_result(system='Darwin', node='fuligule.local', release='24.6.0', version='Darwin Kernel Version 24.6.0: Mon Jul 14 11:30:40 PDT 2025; root:xnu-11417.140.69~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T8132', machine='arm64')},
 {'simd_extensions': {'baseline': ['NEON', 'NEON_FP16', 'NEON_VFPV4', 'ASIMD'],
                      'found': ['ASIMDHP'],
                      'not_found': ['ASIMDFHM']}},
 {'architecture': 'VORTEX',
  'filepath': '/Users/ogrisel/miniforge3/envs/dev/lib/libopenblas.0.dylib',
  'internal_api': 'openblas',
  'num_threads': 10,
  'prefix': 'libopenblas',
  'threading_layer': 'openmp',
  'user_api': 'blas',
  'version': '0.3.30'},
 {'filepath': '/Users/ogrisel/miniforge3/envs/dev/lib/libomp.dylib',
  'internal_api': 'openmp',
  'num_threads': 10,
  'prefix': 'libomp',
  'user_api': 'openmp',
  'version': None}]
```

### Context for the issue:

Fixing this would allow scikit-learn to properly work with PyTorch 2.9 that now includes support for DLPack 1.0 when enabling the array API support of scikit-learn.

Under the hood, scikit-learn would like the following code should either directly to do the device transfer by itself or raise `BufferError` as specified in the standard so that scikit-learn needs to fall back to library specific device to CPU transfer.

```python
>>> import torch
>>> import numpy as np
>>> torch.from_dlpack(np.ones(3, dtype=np.float32), device="mps")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  Cell In[56], line 1
    torch.from_dlpack(np.ones(3, dtype=np.float32), device="mps")
  File ~/miniforge3/envs/tmp/lib/python3.13/site-packages/torch/utils/dlpack.py:159 in from_dlpack
    dlpack = ext_tensor.__dlpack__(**kwargs)
ValueError: unsupported device requested
```

comment.body:
> this function must raise BufferError

It seems a strange choice when the error is connected to the values passed in, but OK

issue.title: BUG: numpy.einsum with ellipses has different behavior when optimize=True or False.
issue.body:
### Describe the issue:

The following einsum works as expected when optimize=True but throws a ValueError when optimize=False. I believe the correct behavior is the one from optimize=True.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np
x = np.array([[[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]], [[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]], [[1,2,3], [1,2,3], [1,2,3]]])
np.einsum('i...->i', x, optimize=True)
# array([18, 18, 18])
np.einsum('i...->i', x)
# ValueError: output has more dimensions than subscripts given in einstein sum, but no '...' ellipsis provided to broadcast the extra dimensions
```

### Error message:

```shell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<python-input-0>", line 5, in <module>
    np.einsum('i...->i', x)
    ~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "[...]/venv/lib/python3.13/site-packages/numpy/_core/einsumfunc.py", line 1423, in einsum
    return c_einsum(*operands, **kwargs)
ValueError: output has more dimensions than subscripts given in einstein sum, but no '...' ellipsis provided to broadcast the extra dimensions.
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

2.3.3
3.13.7 (main, Aug 15 2025, 12:34:02) [GCC 15.2.1 20250813]

### Runtime Environment:

[{'numpy_version': '2.3.3',
  'python': '3.13.7 (main, Aug 15 2025, 12:34:02) [GCC 15.2.1 20250813]',
  'uname': uname_result(system='Linux', node='desktop', release='6.17.1-arch1-1', version='#1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Mon, 06 Oct 2025 18:48:29 +0000', machine='x86_64')},
 {'simd_extensions': {'baseline': ['SSE', 'SSE2', 'SSE3'],
                      'found': ['SSSE3',
                                'SSE41',
                                'POPCNT',
                                'SSE42',
                                'AVX',
                                'F16C',
                                'FMA3',
                                'AVX2'],
                      'not_found': ['AVX512F',
                                    'AVX512CD',
                                    'AVX512_KNL',
                                    'AVX512_KNM',
                                    'AVX512_SKX',
                                    'AVX512_CLX',
                                    'AVX512_CNL',
                                    'AVX512_ICL',
                                    'AVX512_SPR']}}]
>>>

### Context for the issue:

This was one of the first things I tried after learning about einsum. It seemed like a simpler alternative to summing over every axis except the first in a tensor whose number of dimensions is not known in advance.

```python
np.einsum('i...->i', x)
```

comment.body: OK, thanks for peeking
